definitions.definition: to provide somebody with a room or place to sleep, live or sit

examples.text: The hotel can accommodate up to 500 guests.
The aircraft is capable of accommodating 28 passengers.

definitions.definition: to provide enough space for somebody/something

examples.text: The garage can accommodate three cars.
The old town hall now accommodates a Folk Museum.

definitions.definition: to consider something such as somebody’s opinion or a fact and be influenced by it when you are deciding what to do or explaining something

examples.text: Our proposal tries to accommodate the special needs of minority groups.
She modified her views so as to accommodate the objections of American feminists.

definitions.definition: to help somebody by doing what they want

examples.text: I have accommodated the press a great deal, giving numerous interviews.
I’m sure the bank will be able to accommodate you.

definitions.definition: to change your behaviour so that you can deal with a new situation better

examples.text: I needed to accommodate to the new schedule.

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent.: from Latin accommodat- ‘made fitting’, from the verb accommodare, from ad- ‘to’ + commodus ‘fitting’.
